title: Identify People for Screening
description:
Select an option to see more details:


 Systematic Strategy

For the screening of DM and atherosclerosis risk factors, a systematic strategy should be used to identify people who are likely to be at high risk.


 Opportunistic Assessment

Opportunistic assessment can also be used to identify ASCVD risk in the population but should not be the main strategy.




Screen the following people for prediabetes, T2DM and related ASCVD risk factors:
  • Everyone over the age of 40 years.
  • Everyone ≥ 30 years of age with a BMI of ≥23.
  • All women with a history of either GDM or PCOS.
  • All people with a BMI ≥27 kg/m2.
  • Screen all adults with two or more of the following risk factors.




 BMI ≥23 to <27 kg/m2.
 First-degree relative with DM.
 First-degree relative with CVD at young age (<55 years for a           male relative and <65 year for a female relative).
 High-risk race/ethnicity.
 History of CVD.
 Hypertension (BP ≥140/90 mmHg or on therapy for           hypertension).
 Dyslipidaemia: HDL cholesterol level <0.90 mmol/L (35 mg/dL), a           triglyceride level >2.82 mmol/L (250 mg/dL), LDL cholesterol level

          > 3.11 mmol/L (120 mg/dL), total cholesterol level >6.18 mmol/L

          (240 mg/dL), and/or non-HDL cholesterol > 3.63 mmol/L (150

          mg/dL); or the patient is on a lipid lowering medication.
 Physical inactivity.
 Tobacco use.
 Other clinical conditions associated with insulin resistance.

title: ASCVD and DM Risk Factors
description:
Non-Modifiable Risk Factors

Non-Modifiable Risk FactorASCVD Risk FactorT2DM Risk Factor
AgeAge > 40 yearsAge ≥40 years
GenderMen have a higher prevalence of coronary artery disease until the age of 75 years.Women with a previous history of GDM or previous delivery of a baby weighing ≥4 kg (9 lb) are at higher risk of diabetes
Family historyFamily history of premature ASCVD.Family history of T2DM.
EthnicityMember of an at-risk racial or ethnic subgroup e.g. South Asian.

Modifiable Risk Factors

Modifiable Risk FactorASCVD Risk FactorT2DM Risk Factor
Metabolic syndromeAge >YesYes
Impaired glucose metabolismYesYes
Diabetes mellitusYesDiagnosed
HypertensionYesYes
DyslipidaemiaYesYes
Tobacco useYesYes
Sedentary lifestyleYesYes
Unhealthy dietYesYes
Psychosocial stressYesYes
OverweightYesYes

title:
Depression & Anxiety 
Screening & Assessment
description:
Select an option to see more details:



Screening for undiagnosed depression and anxiety should be performed in all adults, including pregnant and postpartum women, who are to be screened for ASCVD or DM.



Use the PHQ-2 and GAD-2 questions for initial screening for depression and anxiety. If a patient answers positively to the PHQ-2 and/or GAD-2 questions, they should be assessed using the PHQ-9 and/ or GAD-7 questions, respectively, and be seen by a physician.



All positive screening results should lead to additional assessment that considers:
 The severity of depression and anxiety.
 First-degree relative with DM.
 Comorbid psychological problems (e.g., anxiety, panic attacks, or           substance abuse).
 Other medical conditions.

title: Measure BMI
description:
Select an option to see more details:



Calculate the BMI by measuring weight in kilograms and height in metres.

BMI should be interpreted with caution because the calculation alone it is not a direct measure of adiposity, especially in highly muscular adults. Do not use bio-impedance as a substitute for BMI as evidence to support its use is lacking at present.




Obesity is commonly defined by a measurement of BMI of ≥30 kg/m2 in Western populations, however different ethnic-specific cut points for defining obesity may need to be considered. Emerging evidence points towards lower BMI levels being associated with greater risk for metabolic diseases based on ethnicity.

The degree of overweight and obesity can be classified:

BMIObesity Class
BMI 25.00 - 29.99 kg/m2Overweight
BMI 30.00 - 34.99 kg/m2Obesity Class I
BMI 35.00 - 39.99 kg/m2Obesity Class II
BMI ≥40.00 kg/m2Obesity Class III (extreme obesity)



 Adults are identified at increased risk for CVD at:           
  • BMI 25.00 - 29.99 kg/m2 – Overweight
  • BMI ≥30 kg/m2 – Obesity
 Adults are identified at increased risk for of death from all causes           at BMI ≥30 kg/m2 (Obesity).

title: Measure Waist Circumference
description:
Select an option to see more details:



Follow the WHO STEPS protocol for measuring waist circumference:
Measure waist circumference, locate the upper hip bone and the top of the right iliac crest. Place a measuring tape in a horizontal plane around the abdomen at the level of the iliac crest. Before reading the tape measure, ensure that the tape is snug, but does not compress the skin, and is parallel to the floor. The measurement is made at the end of a normal expiration.



Consider measuring waist circumference in people with a BMI ≤35 kg/m2.



For screening and risk assessment purposes in people of Middle Eastern ethnicity, use a waist circumference threshold of ≥90 cm (35 inches) in men and ≥80 cm (31.5 inches) in women for diagnosing central adiposity. However, thresholds for acceptable waist circumferences vary between ethnic groups. The table below outlines the upper limits of acceptable waist circumferences in different ethnic groups.

Ethnic GroupWaist Circumference Thresholds
EuropeanMen
Women		≥ 94 cm (37 inches)≥ 80 cm (31.5 inches)
South Asian, Chinese or JapaneseMen
Women		≥ 90 cm (35 inches) ≥ 80 cm (31.5 inches)
Middle EasternUse South Asian recommendations until more specific data are available [R-GDG].
Ethnic south and central AmericanUse South Asian recommendations until more specific data are available
Sub-Saharan AfricanUse European data until more specific data are available



Waist circumference along with BMI can be used as a measure to assess risk; however, if the BMI is >35 kg/m2, the waist circumference does not add to the absolute measure of risk. A larger waist circumference is a recognised risk factor of developing atherosclerosis and DM in an individual.

title: Measure Neck Circumference
description:
Neck circumference (NC) is considered a simple and accurate way of assessing overweight and obesity in adults.


NC should be measured with the individual standing erect with their head positioned in the horizontal plane. The superior border of a tape measure should be placed just below the laryngeal prominence and applied perpendicular to the long axis of the neck.



NC above ≥40 cm in Caucasian men and ≥34cm in Caucasian women are associated with increased cardio-metabolic risk. Precise cut-offs in the Qatari population remain to be determined.

title: Measure Blood Pressure
description:
Correct measurement of blood pressure (BP) is essential for accurate determination of ASCVD risk.


Steps for Blood Measurement


 Patient's Preparation

Ensure the patient:
  • Relaxes for more than 5 minutes, sitting in a chair with their feet on the floor and back supported.
  • Avoids caffeine, exercise, and smoking for at least 30 min before BP is measured.
  • Has an empty bladder.
  • Does not talk during the rest time or during BP measurement:
  • Removes all clothing covering the area where the cuff will be placed.

BP measured while the patient is sitting or lying on an examining table does not fulfil these criteria

 Technique for BP Measurement

Use correct technique for BP measurement:
  • The BP device should have been validated and should be calibrated periodically.
  • The person’s arm should be supported (e.g. resting on a desk).
  • The middle of the cuff should be placed on the patient’s upper arm at the level of the right atrium (the midpoint of the sternum).
  • The correct cuff size should be used, ensuring the bladder encircles 80% of the arm.
  • he diaphragm or bell of the stethoscope can be used for auscultatory readings.
  • Palpate the radial or brachial pulse to check for pulse irregularity.

If the pulse is irregular:

Do not use automated devices.

Measure BP manually using direct auscultation over the brachial artery.



BP cuff size selection in adults showing arm circumference to cuff size.
  • 22 to 26 cm for a small adult.
  • 27 to 34 cm for an average adult.
  • 35 to 44 cm for a large adult.
  • 45 to 52 cm for an adult thigh

 Measurement Take


Take the correct measurements for diagnosis of elevated BP/hypertension:
  • At the first visit, the BP should be recorded in both arms.
  • The arm that gives the higher BP reading should be used for any further readings.
  • Consistent inter‐arm differences of over 20/10 mmHg may suggest pathology warranting specialist referral.

Repeat BP measurements should be done 15 minutes apart, if abnormal.

How to Measure BP When Using an Auscultatory Method


Palpate the radial pulse for obliteration to estimate the systolic blood pressure (SBP).
  • The cuff should be inflated 20 to 30 mmHg above the pulse obliteration level to assess the BP level by auscultation.
  • The cuff pressure should be deflated by 2 mmHg per second while listening for Korotkoff sounds.

    •  BP Readings Documentation


    Document accurate BP readings correctly.
    • Note the SBP and diastolic blood pressure (DBP).
    • Document what time the most recent BP medication was taken before the BP was measured.
    • Use an average of ≥2 readings to estimate the BP level, if abnormal.

    If using the auscultatory method record:

    SBP at onset of the first Korotkoff sound
    DBP at disappearance of all Korotkoff sounds
    Use the nearest even number.



     BP Classification


    For high blood pressure prevention and treatment, BP should be categorized as detailed in the table below. If readings for a patient fall into two categories, the higher category should be selected.
    BP CategorySBPAnd/OrDBP
    Normal BP< 120 mmHgMAnd< 80 mmHg
    Elevated BP120-129 mmHgAnd< 80 mmHg
    Hypertension Stage 1130-139 mmHgOr80-89 mmHg
    Hypertension Stage 2≥ 140 mmHgOr≥ 90 mmHg

title: Blood Tests
description:
Undertake the following screening blood tests:

 Glycated haemoglobin (HBA1c).
 Fasting glucose (if possible).
 Fasting or non-fasted, lipids.

 When using HBA1c, it should be noted that:

 Using HBA1c to screen for prediabetes may be problematic in adults           with certain haemoglobinopathies or conditions that affect red blood
          cell turnover.
 Testing should be performed in a laboratory using a method that is           NGSP-certified and standardised to the DCCT assay.

title: ASCVD Risk Calculation
description:
ASCVD risk calculation tool

The ACC/AHA Pooled Cohort Equations should be used to estimate 10-year ASCVD risk in appropriate individuals with or without diabetes.

The tool can only provide an approximate value of ASCVD risk − interpretation of risk scores should always reflect informed clinical judgement.

The App should be used for primary prevention patients (those without ASCVD) only.



Risk estimation tools should not be used for the following groups of patients:
  • People aged over 75 years
  • Patients with a primary dyslipidemia.
  • Patients with established CVD.
  • Patients with T1DM ASCVD risk assessment should be based on the individual’s age and the duration since diagnosis.
  • Patients with Chronic kidney disease (CKD) stages 3-5.

Risk Stratification


Patients without established clinical ASCVD who are at increased risk of ASCVD include:

 Patients with risk score of ≥5% over 10 years -         calculated using the ACC/AHA Pooled Cohort         Equations; or


 Any of the following groups:

  • People aged over 75 years.
  • Patients with a primary dyslipidemia.
  • Patients with established CVD.
  • Patients with T1DM. ASCVD risk assessment should be based on the patient’s age and the duration since diagnosis.
  • Patients with CKD stages 3-5.
  • Patients with an LDL cholesterol of ≥4.9 mmol/L.

 People at low risk of ASCVD include those aged <75         years without clinical ASCVD; and with a calculated         ASCVD risk score of <5% over 10 years.


Communication of risk assessment

When communicating to the screened individual about their risk assessment and treatment, offer information on their risk of ASCVD, the benefits and harms of either intervention or failure to intervene.
Forms to offer information

 Individualised risk and benefit scenarios.

 Risk of events numerically.

 Diagrams and text.

title: Diagnosis of T2DM
description:
T2DM is diagnosed if any of the following criteria are met:

 HBA1C of ≥6.5%.

 Fasting plasma glucose ≥7.0 mmol/L (126 mg/dL).

 2-hour plasma glucose of ≥11.1 mmol/L (200 mg/dL)         during an oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT)         performed using a glucose load containing the         equivalent of 75g of anhydrous glucose dissolved in        water.


It is recommended that single tests, such as HBA1C and fasting glucose, be repeated for confirmation.

title: Management of T2DM
description:
Type 2 Diabetes mellitus:

 Should be managed predominantly in a primary care         setting.

 Complex cases should be referred to secondary         care.


Refer to the MOPH National Clinical Guidelines on Diabetes for detailed information on management.

title: Diagnosis of Prediabetes
description:
Prediabetes is diagnosed if any of the following criteria are met:
  • HBA1C of 5.7% - 6.4%
  • Fasting plasma glucose 5.6 - 6.9 mmol/L (100 - 125 mg/dL).
  • 2-hour plasma glucose 7.8 - 11.0 mmol/L (140 - 199 mg/dL) during OGTT performed using a glucose load containing the equivalent of 75g of anhydrous glucose dissolved in water.

It is recommended that single tests, such as HBA1C and fasting glucose, be repeated for confirmation.

title: Management of Prediabetes
description:
Healthy lifestyle intervention


Those with prediabetes should:
 Be referred to an intensive behavioural lifestyle intervention           programme (e.g. Wellness Centers or health educators in primary           care).
 Achieve weight loss
 Increase physical activity.
 Use Technology-assisted tools
 Participate in Diabetes self-management education (DSME) and           support (DSMS) programmes
 Participate in traditional face-to-face and coach-driven programmes.

Nutrition & Weight management


Refer all adults at high risk for T2DM and those diagnosed with prediabetes to a dietitian for individualised medical nutrition therapy.

Refer to the MOPH National Clinical Guideline on Obesity for detailed information on management of the condition.


Physical activity

In adults with prediabetes suggest 150 minutes per week of moderate intensity physical activity e.g., brisk walking.

Medication

Metformin treatment in prediabetes for prevention of T2DM has the strongest evidence base and long-term safety profile.

Who should be medicated?

Should be considered in everyone with prediabetes (if there are no contraindications), and especially in the following groups:
  • People with a BMI ≥ 27 kg/m2.
  • People aged < 60 years.
  • Women with prior gestational diabetes mellitus.

Dosage

Metformin dose should be slowly titrated upwards up to a dose of 1,000 mg twice a day or maximum tolerated dose.

People with prediabetes should be screened and treated for other modifiable risk factors of ASCVD.


Monitoring

At least annual monitoring should be performed to check for the development of diabetes. This should include:
  • HBA1C.
  • Fasting and postprandial glucose.

In patients on metformin, annual measurement of vitamin B12 levels should be carried out.

title:
No Diagnosis 
 of DM or Prediabetes
description: When there is no diagnosis of Diabetes Mellitus (DM) or prediabetes, diabetes risk calculation should be the next step.

title: Diabetes Risk Calculation
description:
Risk assessment tool for those not identified with prediabetes or diabetes:
 The ADA risk calculator should be used to calculate the risk of developing diabetes.
 A score of ≥5 indicates an increased risk of T2DM.

Confirmation by a doctor of a diagnosis of T2DM or prediabetes is recommended.
Risk Test

title: Other Diagnoses
description:
Some other conditions can also be diagnosed during diabetes screening:
 Dyslipidemia
 Hypertension
 Overweight or obesity
 Cessation of tobacco use
 Depression
Refer to the MOPH National Clinical Guidelines for detailed information on management.

title: Lifestyle Improvement Advice
description:
All people should be encouraged to follow heart healthy lifestyle habits including:
  • Adhering to a heart-healthy diet.
  • Maintenance of a healthy body weight.
  • Regular physical activity habits:
    • Aim for reducing sedentariness and increasing walking, progressing to moderate-intensity physical activity (such as brisk walking), gradually increased to at least 150 min/week.
    • Consider using the Physical Activity Readiness Questionnaire for Safe Exercise (PARQ) to assess an individual’s safety to commence exercise.
    • Those individuals considered at high risk of ASCVD should be referred to a cardiologist for review prior to commencing exercise.
  • Cessation of tobacco products.

title: Frequency of Repeat Screening
description:
Frequency of Screening

Screening should occur at the following intervals:

In all adults, aged over 40 years
  • Screen every 3 years.
  • Consider further annual screening, if risk factors are identified.

In adults aged less than 40 years, with two or more of risk factors

  • Initial screening should be performed at the time the person is identified, and thereafter the individual should undergo treatment of any identified disease or risk factors.
  • Those undergoing treatment for hypertension and/or dyslipidemia – screen for DM and prediabetes, annually.
  • In all other cases, repeat screening at least every 3 years.

Frequency of atherosclerosis risk assessment

In adults who are free from ASCVD:
  • Estimate 10-year ASCVD risk every 4-6 years in adults 40-75 years of age.
  • Risk assessment should be repeated every 4–6 years in adults who are found to be at low 10-year risk (<5%).
  • Consider assessment of 30-year or lifetime ASCVD risk on the basis of traditional risk factors in adults 20–59 years of age who are free from ASCVD and are not at high or intermediate short-term risk (10-year <5%).
